Author: laut
Content:
Have you read Bastiat?

http://bastiat.org/en/twisatwins.html#broken_window

What is not seen is all the businesses that are not started. What is not seen is how business could deliver better products/services, that people would want, but don't because of government regulation. And so on.

Content: Some people think they can cut corners and fool others.

Author: vnorby
Content: Research shows that when common sense is supported by research it seems more credible.

Author: litewulf
Content:
Steve Yegge's js2-mode is pretty freaking awesome for emacs users.

Yay emacs. It also has built in linting for things like inconsistent returns and so forth. Its kind of amazingly good.

Author: litewulf
Content:
One of the most disappointing things by far is that things are so unfinished.

HTTPS keeps being promised, other languages, being able to pay for higher quotas, etc etc etc.

Not to mention the datastore is freaking weird and painful to use. Scalablity is all well and good but I'd rather write my site quickly and scale when needed. If all I'm going to do is make an app for me and my friends, I don't want the gods of scaling to demand virgin sacrifices just to do simple things.

Author: mattmaroon
Content:
It supports cookies just fine. It just doesn't send your info to every third party site that has a pixel on the page.

Now for Google to track you as you move around the web, they'll have to do a lot more than simply give people a JS snippet to slap in their pages. That's the point. It won't make it impossible for them, but it could make it impractical.

The article probably didn't explain it so well because it was aimed at a non-technical audience.

Author: silencio
Content: I'm actually impressed and not at all suspicious over the fact that every single device my boyfriend owns is as secure as he can manage. He'll willingly let me view all the text messages and emails and whatnot that I want (even for work, as long as I don't tell anyone..), but you know, those pesky strangers and pesky people who might steal your phone or laptop...

Author: soundsop
Title: Comp.lang.lisp discussion about loops and cache line alignment

Author: davidw
Content:
> The DMCA is screwing a ton of potential music startups. Tipjoy is in a ridiculously regulated space of finance. Plenty of YC startups get screwed by immigration laws.

Like I said below, those are pretty good examples, but "America's small businesses" are not primarily comprised of that sort of thing. I guess I just reacted to the blanket "government is the problem" statement, which I feel is inaccurate. It's certainly a problem, but not the problem for most businesses. It's also a source of many benefits for businesses, such as an educated workforce, infrastructure, enforcement of contracts, but that's getting into an extremely long, drawn out and complicated argument: "the ideal level of government", that is guaranteed to go nowhere. I think we can all agree that certain things ought to be streamlined, though.

Author: mattmaroon
Content: Define long term. Every time I see an article from the 40s describing today, they've got us all in flying cars.

Author: psyklic
Content:
Sounds a little suspicious --

"During the first week each participant will be oriented to their living space, office/work space, ... and reality TV crew and cameras." (emphasis added)

Author: davidw
Content: Yes, I have, and it's one I feel is fairly accurate.  Do you have some counterexamples of where life for new, small businesses is easier in Europe?  There might be a few: the Estonian corporate tax is supposed to be pretty good; the UK and Ireland aren't as expensive as continental Europe, but by and large, I stand by my statement.
